candidates.mechanism_1: Transmission rate increases with infected density. Recovery rate decreases infection duration. When transmission exceeds recovery (R0>1), epidemic spreads exponentially. Vaccination reduces susceptible population shifting R0 below 1. Spatial heterogeneity creates local pockets where R0 varies.
candidates.mechanism_2: Proliferation limitations determine spreading dynamics. Growth arrest causes superlinear spreading at reduced rate. Pressure-limited growth produces linear constant-speed spreading. Nutrient-limited growth exhibits phase transition: superlinear when nutrient supply is high, sublinear when depleted. Nutrient supply and conversion efficiency determine phase boundary. Spreading rate distinguishes dominant limitation type.

candidates.mechanism_1: Phase transition in optimal strategy based on task difficulty regime. System exhibits qualitatively different behaviors (power decay vs warmup-stable-decay) separated by sharp threshold determined by ratio of signal learning rate to noise forgetting capacity. Easy-task regime benefits from gradual decay, hard-task regime requires maintaining peak resources until near completion.
candidates.mechanism_2: Qualitative phase transition via spectral condensation at criticality. Progressive reentrant coupling drives system toward infrared critical regime where extensive band of slow collective modes emerges (spectral condensation), reorganizing dynamics qualitatively. Creates emergent capabilities absent at subcritical regime - transition in kind not degree, regardless of system scale.

candidates.mechanism_1: Individual semantic network topology determines ideational breadth. When agents exchange ideation traces, lower initial overlap predicts larger stimulation gains. Shared inspiration sources create network-level redundancy, forming feedback between individual cognitive structure and collective outcomes.
candidates.mechanism_2: Transfer learning with structured graph representations enables few-shot adaptation across related domains by identifying shared interaction principles from well-studied systems and rapidly adapting to new contexts with minimal training data.

candidates.mechanism_1: Particle motion in extremal configurations exhibits positive Lyapunov exponents indicating sensitivity to initial conditions. Chaos persists even at zero temperature. System parameters (spin, charge) modulate chaos strength - increasing one parameter strengthens chaotic behavior while the other weakens it.
candidates.mechanism_2: Species cross-feed through metabolite leakage and uptake. Competitive uptake of leaked chemicals creates coupled population-chemical dynamics. Network structure determines attractor types: fixed points, limit cycles, low-dimensional chaos, or high-dimensional chaos. High-dimensional chaos enables coexistence beyond competitive exclusion limits through intermittent switching among quasi-stationary states. Chemical dynamics explore high-dimensional space while populations switch intermittently.

candidates.mechanism_1: Cooperation and disease transmission coevolve through network structure. Structural heterogeneity creates leverage points - highly connected hubs adopt protection due to amplified risk, catalyzing cooperation. Cost heterogeneity creates weakest links - low-risk individuals free-ride and act as disease reservoirs, undermining cooperation. Heterogeneity is double-edged: influence asymmetry facilitates cooperation, motivation asymmetry degrades it.
candidates.mechanism_2: Non-local quantum correlations enable superior coordination in distributed systems with convex reward functions: instantaneous shared randomness from entanglement avoids communication latency costs when longer uninterrupted processing yields superlinear rewards.

candidates.mechanism_1: Spatial structure and dispersal networks jointly determine species persistence. Heterogeneous habitats support stable coexistence only above a critical heterogeneity threshold. Homogeneous environments allow coexistence only in a fine-tuned marginal state, creating instability. Network topology encodes dispersal effectiveness through an effective kernel.
candidates.mechanism_2: Higher-order network structure (beyond pairwise) shapes imitation dynamics through group-dependent adoption rates. Information diversity achieved through structured sampling from local neighborhoods. Adoption probability depends on group composition and size, not just neighbor count. Network hypergraph structure determines equilibrium strategy distributions through sampling bias.

candidates.mechanism_1: Learned selective information sharing across parallel exploration processes. Multiple independent teams explore different solution trajectories with learned controller deciding which intermediate results to place in globally-accessible shared memory. Balances exploration diversity (parallel independence) against computational efficiency (reuse of overlapping sub-solutions), using stepwise credit assignment to identify globally useful information.
candidates.mechanism_2: Surrogate-assisted proposal generation with dynamic correction bounds enables efficient exploration when exact evaluations are expensive: surrogate provides cheap proposals, dynamic offset enforcement maintains correctness.

candidates.mechanism_1: As a system approaches a bifurcation point, convergence to steady state slows dramatically. Near criticality, relaxation time diverges according to universal scaling laws. The system exhibits characteristic critical exponents that govern short-time behavior, asymptotic decay, and crossover between regimes.
candidates.mechanism_2: Phase transition in optimal strategy based on task difficulty regime. System exhibits qualitatively different behaviors (power decay vs warmup-stable-decay) separated by sharp threshold determined by ratio of signal learning rate to noise forgetting capacity. Easy-task regime benefits from gradual decay, hard-task regime requires maintaining peak resources until near completion.

candidates.mechanism_1: Individuals' opinions and network edge weights coevolve through coupled dynamics. Interaction strength depends on opinion distance. Similar opinions strengthen network connections. Connection strength amplifies opinion influence. This creates feedback between opinion convergence and network structure formation. Interaction function form determines emergent structures and stability.
candidates.mechanism_2: Microbial communities operate near edge of instability - transition from stable fixed-point to chaos controlled by network sparsity and interaction heterogeneity. Effective stability parameter inferred from pairwise covariance distribution width. Healthy gut microbiomes cluster near instability edge with broader associations; dysbiosis shifts toward stable regimes with narrower association distributions.

candidates.mechanism_1: When agents fall below a resource threshold, they solicit resources from connected neighbors based on relatedness. Redistribution creates feedback between kinship network structure and reproduction ability. This enables population survival at lower resource densities but increases network heterogeneity and local centralization.
candidates.mechanism_2: Semantic network topology determines ideational breadth - low modularity yields broader exploration. When agents exchange ideation traces, lower pre-interaction overlap predicts larger stimulation gains. Shared inspiration sources create network-level redundancy as convergent semantic neighborhoods limit diversity of generated ideas.

candidates.mechanism_1: Transmission rate increases with infected density. Recovery rate decreases infection duration. When transmission exceeds recovery (R0>1), epidemic spreads exponentially. Vaccination reduces susceptible population shifting R0 below 1. Spatial heterogeneity creates local pockets where R0 varies.
candidates.mechanism_2: Environmental state dominates progression dynamics over intrinsic mutation rates in spatially structured systems: supportive environments amplify weak growth signals into invasive spread, while inhibitory environments suppress even high-mutation populations.

candidates.mechanism_1: Funding rates in perpetual futures impose economic costs on leveraged positions. High funding creates pressure to reduce directional exposure. Capital rebalancing occurs when funding costs exceed expected returns. Funding mechanisms act as negative feedback regulating trader behavior - extreme positions become economically unsustainable, creating mean-reverting pressure that defines trading ranges.
candidates.mechanism_2: Dynamic resource allocation adapts commitment timing to local uncertainty: allocating more processing to uncertain regions while quickly committing to certain regions avoids premature decisions and improves both quality and efficiency.

candidates.mechanism_1: The ratio between diffusion and drift (Feller condition) determines qualitative migration properties. High diffusion relative to drift creates randomized, intermittent movement patterns. Low ratio produces more deterministic, continuous movement. This ratio acts as a control parameter governing timescale-dependent behavioral transitions.
candidates.mechanism_2: Strategy distributions evolve through selection (performance-based survival), innovation (mutation), and environmental perturbation (external shocks). Individual agents adapt using local signals while population composition shifts based on relative fitness. Two-layer adaptation - individual learning plus population-level evolution - determines whether strategies persist, collapse, or form coalitions.

candidates.mechanism_1: Token-mediated dependencies create dense inter-component connections. A shock to one component propagates through dependency links causing contagion effects. Network topology and link weights determine the extent and path of cascading failures across the system.
candidates.mechanism_2: Multiple branched actin networks compete for shared monomer pool. Network growth locally depletes monomers creating negative feedback between network density and growth rate. Local depletion couples network growth rates through shared resource. Under weak competition, networks coexist at steady state. Under strong competition, selection replaces coexistence - fastest-growing network excludes others. Competition strength determined by monomer availability and consumption rates.

candidates.mechanism_1: Cell size feedback operates through size deviations (difference between absolute size and cell-cycle progression). Feedback from size to growth rate and cycle timing creates coupled dynamics. In linear regime, dynamics reduce to stochastically forced harmonic oscillator. Cell-cycle timing and intrinsic fluctuations jointly shape size control strategy. Mechanistic feedback structure may differ from apparent coarse-grained correlations due to noise integration.
candidates.mechanism_2: Multi-scale pattern formation via coupled reaction-diffusion and particle assembly. Classical Turing mechanism (single length scale from reaction-diffusion balance) coupled to finite-size particle assembly driven by background chemical gradient (diffusiophoresis) plus particle-particle interactions. Introduces additional control parameters (particle size, Péclet number, interaction strength) creating imperfections, grain textures, and multi-scale structures.

candidates.mechanism_1: Cognitive gap-guided integration of noisy real-world feedback. candidates.mechanism_2: Systems with delayed feedback combined with censored observations face fundamental learning limitations compared to systems with immediate uncensored feedback, creating a sharp performance separation even with identical optimization algorithms.

Below threshold density, vegetation collapses due to weakened facilitation (spatial Allee effect).

Flow patterns optimize based on nutrient source locations. Network adapts topology through tube reinforcement when flow is high and tube degradation when flow is low. This creates an intelligent search for optimal transport paths through flow-structure feedback.

candidates.mechanism_1: System state evolves discretely through iterated function. Scaling symmetry preserves dynamics under magnification/contraction. candidates.mechanism_1: Quantum systems undergo measurement-induced phase transitions when unitary evolution competes with measurements. Below critical measurement rate, volume-law entanglement dominates. Above critical rate, area-law entanglement emerges. Measurement rate acts as control parameter for phase transition. candidates.mechanism_2: Measurement gentleness constraint (α-bounded state perturbation) imposes information extraction penalty. Sample complexity scales as d/α² - the trade-off between disturbance and information parallels privacy mechanisms. Gentler measurements require more samples but preserve quantum state for reuse, creating fundamental efficiency-preservation trade-off.

candidates.mechanism_1: Intermittent resource pulses interact with positive density dependence (Allee effects) to generate irregular spatial clusters. During favorable pulses, local facilitation enables patch expansion; during scarcity, neighborhood density determines survival. Resilience emerges from spatial covariance and local density rather than total biomass.
candidates.mechanism_2: Coupled multi-timescale dynamics with threshold-based control transition. Fast epidemiological process coupled to slow ecological oscillation, where amplitude of slow cycle determines disease persistence via threshold (ecological reproduction number). Natural control sufficient above threshold; below threshold requires engineered intervention to navigate both timescales simultaneously.

candidates.mechanism_1: Three behavioral types interact: conformists benefit from choosing common strategies, nonconformists profit from rare strategies, and imitators copy highest earners. Population proportions fluctuate in finite populations but equilibrate as population size increases. Strategy proportions undergo perpetual oscillations in small populations, but fluctuation amplitudes approach zero in large populations through stochastic averaging.
candidates.mechanism_2: Manipulators with high budgets attempt to distort prediction market prices. Informed traders with correct beliefs observe price distortions and increase their opposing bets. Market depth and information heterogeneity determine manipulation effectiveness. When information is dispersed, manipulation can temporarily move prices, but informed arbitrage eventually corrects mispricing. Manipulator budget and trader information quality create a competitive dynamic.

candidates.mechanism_1: Time-periodic stiffness variation induces parametric excitation in coupled components. System parameters (stiffness degree, mass symmetry, friction) determine stability boundaries and response amplitude.
candidates.mechanism_2: Parallel networks with distinct failure modes enable large reversible deformations: brittle bond network governs initial stiffness and yield point, entropic elastic network enables large deformations post-yield; reorganization and rebonding during recovery locks new equilibrium with increased stiffness.

candidates.mechanism_1: Stablecoin prices de-peg during stress events. Arbitrageurs restore the peg by trading against deviations. Arbitrage profitability depends on deviation magnitude and transaction costs. Insufficient arbitrage activity allows persistent de-pegging. candidates.mechanism_2: High-budget agents (whales) shift market prices proportionally to their capital share. Distortion duration depends on non-whale learning rates and herding intensity. Fast learners correct distortions quickly; herding amplifies and prolongs whale influence as coordinated followers reinforce biased prices even when informed traders exit.

candidates.mechanism_1: Plants facilitate neighboring growth through local resource modification. Facilitation competes with resource competition. When precipitation is intermittent, facilitation-competition balance creates spatial vegetation patterns. Below threshold density, vegetation collapses due to weakened facilitation (spatial Allee effect).
candidates.mechanism_2: Dynamic resource allocation adapts commitment timing to local uncertainty: allocating more processing to uncertain regions while quickly committing to certain regions avoids premature decisions and improves both quality and efficiency.

candidates.mechanism_1: As a system approaches a bifurcation point, convergence to steady state slows dramatically. Near criticality, relaxation time diverges according to universal scaling laws. The system exhibits characteristic critical exponents that govern short-time behavior, asymptotic decay, and crossover between regimes.
candidates.mechanism_2: Scaling behavior depends jointly on model capacity, training data volume, and input representation structure: different representations yield different scaling exponents, making representation choice as critical as model size for performance.

candidates.mechanism_1: Plants facilitate neighboring growth through local resource modification. Facilitation competes with resource competition. When precipitation is intermittent, facilitation-competition balance creates spatial vegetation patterns. Below threshold density, vegetation collapses due to weakened facilitation (spatial Allee effect).
candidates.mechanism_2: Technology adoption spreads through spatial and network channels. Spatial spillovers and network externalities interact multiplicatively - nearby adoption and connected peer adoption amplify each other. Cumulative adoption pressure accumulates along stochastic paths through spatial-network space. Network position amplifies or dampens spatial effects, creating non-linear adoption dynamics.

candidates.mechanism_1: Markov dynamics combine heterogeneity and asymmetry (broken detailed balance). Heterogeneity parameter controls transition rate variability. Asymmetry parameter controls forward-backward correlation. Critical locus emerges where relaxation times diverge. Entropy production and predictive information depend strongly on heterogeneity but weakly on asymmetry. Near criticality, small heterogeneity changes cause large dynamical shifts.
candidates.mechanism_2: Dual-signal adaptive resource allocation using entropy as proxy for learning value. Global level: relative entropy change identifies high-value samples for prioritized exploration. Local level: absolute entropy peaks identify critical moments within each trajectory. Concentrates computation where information gain is highest rather than uniform distribution.

candidates.mechanism_1: Distributional MDPs steer cumulative reward distribution toward target law rather than optimizing expected value. Randomized Markov policies on augmented state space with characteristic-function loss enable distribution matching. Policy gradient converges to stationary points. Non-uniqueness phenomena emerge - multiple distinct policies can achieve same target distribution.
candidates.mechanism_2: Non-local quantum correlations enable superior coordination in distributed systems with convex reward functions: instantaneous shared randomness from entanglement avoids communication latency costs when longer uninterrupted processing yields superlinear rewards.

candidates.mechanism_1: Microbial communities operate near edge of instability - transition from stable fixed-point to chaos controlled by network sparsity and interaction heterogeneity. Effective stability parameter inferred from pairwise covariance distribution width. Healthy gut microbiomes cluster near instability edge with broader associations; dysbiosis shifts toward stable regimes with narrower association distributions.
candidates.mechanism_2: Population-level inference with uncertainty-aware fusion decouples global dynamics from individual variability: clustering behaviorally similar entities, encoding mechanistic priors, and fusing uncertain predictions at cluster level enables scalable simulation.

candidates.mechanism_1: Local ergodicity in subsystems, rather than global ergodicity, enables thermalization. Subsystem dynamics appear pseudorandom due to local interactions. Statistical properties of observables emerge from this effective local randomization without requiring the entire system to be ergodic.
candidates.mechanism_2: Qualitative phase transition via spectral condensation at criticality. Progressive reentrant coupling drives system toward infrared critical regime where extensive band of slow collective modes emerges (spectral condensation), reorganizing dynamics qualitatively. Creates emergent capabilities absent at subcritical regime - transition in kind not degree, regardless of system scale.

candidates.mechanism_1: Variable group sizes in majority-rule dynamics create heterogeneous influence through effective majority leverage. Rare large-group events can realign substantial population fractions. Critical threshold for independence depends on group-size distribution - heavy-tailed distributions enhance robustness to disorder through occasional macroscopic coordination events.
candidates.mechanism_2: Local monomer depletion creates negative feedback between network density and growth. Epiplexity (structural information encoding) and empowerment (control capacity) provide recognition vs. control axes for physical intelligence. Landauer-scale closed-cycle benchmarks require explicit boundary-closure and reset assumptions - without charging for external low-entropy resources, information gain and dissipation decouple.

candidates.mechanism_1: System state evolves discretely through iterated function. Scaling symmetry preserves dynamics under magnification/contraction. Near fixed points, small perturbations grow exponentially (positive Lyapunov exponent) causing sensitive dependence. Trajectories confined to fractal attractor with non-integer dimension. Chaotic regime characterized by scaling laws and self-similarity across scales.
candidates.mechanism_2: Coupled multi-timescale dynamics with threshold-based control transition. Fast epidemiological process coupled to slow ecological oscillation, where amplitude of slow cycle determines disease persistence via threshold (ecological reproduction number). Natural control sufficient above threshold; below threshold requires engineered intervention to navigate both timescales simultaneously.

candidates.mechanism_1: Pathogen virulence (harm to host) causally influences transmission rate (spread to new hosts). Increased virulence may increase transmission initially but reduces host mobility decreasing spread. Trade-off creates optimal virulence level maximizing transmission. Evolutionary dynamics drive virulence toward this optimum. Past virulence predicts future transmission but not vice versa (directional causality).
candidates.mechanism_2: Higher-order information creates heterogeneous risk perception targeting structural hubs and high-participation nodes, preventing contagion exploitation of these critical paths at lower social cost than uniform interventions.

candidates.mechanism_1: Species cross-feed through metabolite leakage and uptake. Competitive uptake of leaked chemicals creates coupled population-chemical dynamics. Network structure determines attractor types: fixed points, limit cycles, low-dimensional chaos, or high-dimensional chaos. Chemical dynamics explore high-dimensional space while populations switch intermittently.
candidates.mechanism_2: Impulsive periodic intervention under environmental stress. System alternates between autonomous dynamics and discrete intervention events (periodic releases), with environmental perturbations (temperature stress) potentially reversing intervention effects. Success threshold depends on balancing intervention frequency, stress magnitude, and fitness costs to maintain desired state despite continuous environmental pressure.

Noise regulates density and prevents singular concentration through equilibrium states from constrained energy minimization. Stable energy minimizers emerge from interplay between potential-driven interactions and environmental variability.

candidates.mechanism_1: AI use reduces cultural variance in populations. Under individual selection, agents relying heavily on AI (substitutes) outcompete those using AI as complement, despite reducing variance more. Group selection can favor agents that maintain variance through complementary AI use when group boundaries are strong, creating selection-level competition.
candidates.mechanism_2: Threshold-based resource redistribution creates feedback between network structure and resource allocation ability. Agents below threshold solicit help; helpers contribute fractionally based on relatedness. Higher local density and relational closeness emerge as redistribution-dependent survival creates centralized clusters through cooperative resource sharing.

candidates.mechanism_1: A single driving signal applied to one network component suppresses extreme events throughout the system. In coupled components, drive breaks phase-locking between elements. In networked systems, drive disrupts protoevent frequency dynamics causing frequency decoupling that prevents extreme event cascades.
candidates.mechanism_2: Cooperation and disease transmission coevolve through network structure. Structural heterogeneity creates leverage points - highly connected hubs adopt protection due to amplified risk, catalyzing cooperation. Cost heterogeneity creates weakest links - low-risk individuals free-ride and act as disease reservoirs, undermining cooperation. Heterogeneity is double-edged: influence asymmetry facilitates cooperation, motivation asymmetry degrades it.

candidates.mechanism_1: Cell size determined by control mechanisms across cell cycle phases (sizer, timer, adder strategies). Division kernel and phase-specific control govern size distribution. Population-density-dependent regulation limits total cell numbers (extrinsic feedback). Cell-size-dependent regulation suppresses size variability (intrinsic feedback). Trade-off between extrinsic and intrinsic control.
candidates.mechanism_2: Multiple branched actin networks compete for shared monomer pool. Network growth locally depletes monomers creating negative feedback between network density and growth rate. Local depletion couples network growth rates through shared resource. Under weak competition, networks coexist at steady state. Under strong competition, selection replaces coexistence - fastest-growing network excludes others. Competition strength determined by monomer availability and consumption rates.

candidates.mechanism_1: Particle motion in extremal configurations exhibits positive Lyapunov exponents indicating sensitivity to initial conditions. Chaos persists even at zero temperature. System parameters (spin, charge) modulate chaos strength - increasing one parameter strengthens chaotic behavior while the other weakens it.
candidates.mechanism_2: Microbial communities operate near edge of instability - transition from stable fixed-point to chaos controlled by network sparsity and interaction heterogeneity. Effective stability parameter inferred from pairwise covariance distribution width. Healthy gut microbiomes cluster near instability edge with broader associations; dysbiosis shifts toward stable regimes with narrower association distributions.

candidates.mechanism_1: Strategy distributions evolve through selection (performance-based survival), innovation (mutation), and environmental perturbation (external shocks). Individual agents adapt using local signals while population composition shifts based on relative fitness. Two-layer adaptation - individual learning plus population-level evolution - determines whether strategies persist, collapse, or form coalitions.
candidates.mechanism_2: Intermittent resource pulses interact with positive density dependence (Allee effects) to generate irregular spatial clusters. During favorable pulses, local facilitation enables patch expansion; during scarcity, neighborhood density determines survival. Resilience emerges from spatial covariance and local density rather than total biomass.

candidates.mechanism_1: Paradigm shift from static optimization to dynamic resilience in commons management. Early deterministic bioeconomic models established individual-collective efficiency tension. Ostrom turn integrated institutional monitoring and sanctions into game theory. Evolutionary dynamics and behavioral economics relaxed rationality. Stochastic models capture spatial heterogeneity and noise-induced regime shifts with early warning signals.
candidates.mechanism_2: Optimal resource extraction from networked populations balances local growth rates and network-mediated redistribution: harvest intensity should scale with intrinsic productivity and effective incoming flow from connected patches.

candidates.mechanism_1: Semantic network topology determines ideational breadth - low modularity yields broader exploration. When agents exchange ideation traces, lower pre-interaction overlap predicts larger stimulation gains. Shared inspiration sources create network-level redundancy as convergent semantic neighborhoods limit diversity of generated ideas.
candidates.mechanism_2: External behavioral anchors induce strategic compliance and cognitive offloading without genuine norm internalization: agents mimic anchor behavior locally to reduce cognitive load, but revert to self-interested behavior when anchors absent or unobservable.

candidates.mechanism_1: Reciprocal group dynamics and behavioral inertia drive cooperation levels in groups. Cooperation depends on observed group behavior patterns rather than the identity of participants. These normative mechanisms operate identically regardless of agent type, creating stable cooperation patterns through behavioral feedback.
candidates.mechanism_2: Temporal niche differentiation through phenotypic plasticity in circadian rhythms enables species coexistence. Phase-locking of coupled oscillators creates temporal resource partitioning. Plasticity allows dynamic adjustment of activity timing based on competitor presence. Coexistence emerges when plastic responses generate sufficient temporal separation in resource use patterns.

candidates.mechanism_1: When agents fall below a resource threshold, they solicit resources from connected neighbors based on relatedness. Redistribution creates feedback between kinship network structure and reproduction ability. This enables population survival at lower resource densities but increases network heterogeneity and local centralization.
candidates.mechanism_2: High-budget agents (whales) shift market prices proportionally to their capital share. Distortion duration depends on non-whale learning rates and herding intensity. Fast learners correct distortions quickly; herding amplifies and prolongs whale influence as coordinated followers reinforce biased prices even when informed traders exit.

candidates.mechanism_1: Three reduction paradigms form Pareto frontier between computational tractability and physical fidelity: structural coarse-graining (spectral/topological contraction), analytical reduction (moment closures preserving mechanisms), and data-driven reduction (manifold learning prioritizing prediction). Selection governed by no-free-lunch theorem - epistemological trade-off between causal mechanism preservation versus predictive power.
candidates.mechanism_2: Mean-field approximation to reduce coupling density. System replaces dense pairwise constraint interactions with dynamically updated single-node bias terms (mean fields), trading exact global coordination for approximate local summaries that maintain solution quality while dramatically reducing graph density and enabling hardware scalability.

candidates.mechanism_1: Token-mediated dependencies create dense inter-component connections. A shock to one component propagates through dependency links causing contagion effects. Network topology and link weights determine the extent and path of cascading failures across the system.
candidates.mechanism_2: Physarum network morphology responds to environmental stimuli by expanding or retracting tubes. Cytoplasmic flow bidirectionally transports nutrients through the network. Flow patterns optimize based on nutrient source locations. Network adapts topology through tube reinforcement when flow is high and tube degradation when flow is low. This creates an intelligent search for optimal transport paths through flow-structure feedback.

candidates.mechanism_1: Under stress, cells face rapid pathway selection with ATP scarcity. Continuous ATP regeneration rescues sporulation despite 99.7% ATP depletion. GTP accumulates as energy buffer while ATP regenerates preventing complete depletion. Stochastic regulatory transitions couple to continuous metabolic flux. Energy efficiency emerges from interplay between discrete regulatory logic and continuous thermodynamic constraints. System robustness through dynamic energy management enables 16-fold efficiency gain under stress.
candidates.mechanism_2: Online recurrent learning continuously adapts pretrained policies to environmental drift and task changes: biologically-plausible real-time weight updates enable deployed systems to maintain performance under non-stationary conditions.

candidates.mechanism_1: Cell size fluctuates due to noisy growth rates and size-dependent division noise. Size homeostasis mechanisms compensate for fluctuations through size control strategies. Population dynamics alter size distributions compared to single lineages - exponential population growth changes the effective size control measured in constant-volume experiments. Extrinsic growth noise and population structure jointly determine observed size distributions.
candidates.mechanism_2: Stochastic perturbations in nonlocal aggregation systems create gradient-flow structure in Wasserstein space. Noise regulates density and prevents singular concentration through equilibrium states from constrained energy minimization. Stable energy minimizers emerge from interplay between potential-driven interactions and environmental variability.

candidates.mechanism_1: Species cross-feed through metabolite leakage and uptake. Competitive uptake of leaked chemicals creates coupled population-chemical dynamics. Network structure determines attractor types: fixed points, limit cycles, low-dimensional chaos, or high-dimensional chaos. High-dimensional chaos enables coexistence beyond competitive exclusion limits through intermittent switching among quasi-stationary states. Chemical dynamics explore high-dimensional space while populations switch intermittently.
candidates.mechanism_2: Paradigm shift from static optimization to dynamic resilience in commons management. Early deterministic bioeconomic models established individual-collective efficiency tension. Ostrom turn integrated institutional monitoring and sanctions into game theory. Evolutionary dynamics and behavioral economics relaxed rationality. Stochastic models capture spatial heterogeneity and noise-induced regime shifts with early warning signals.

candidates.mechanism_1: Lift sampling granularity from scalar perturbations to equivalence classes (control-flow paths). Multiple parameter values following same code path share gradient information, reducing variance without introducing bias. Information-per-simulation increases by reusing structural similarities in discrete optimization landscape.
candidates.mechanism_2: Residual dynamics modeling via decoupling static topology from temporal fluctuations. System learns isometric latent representation preserving geometric constraints (static topology), then models temporal evolution via relative displacements anchored to initial structure rather than absolute coordinates. Separates invariant structural relationships from dynamic conformational changes, improving computational efficiency while maintaining physical fidelity.
